Kaja Suryanarayana vs Telangana State Election Commission ... on 28 April, 2023

Author: P.Naveen Rao

Bench: P.Naveen Rao

                                  1



            HONOURABLE SRI JUSTICE P.NAVEEN RAO

 CIVIL REVISION PETITION Nos. 2433 OF 2022, 1 AND 9 OF 2023

                          Date:28.04.2023

CRP No. 2433 OF 2022

Between:

Venkatesh Derangula S/o Kondaiah Derangula
Aged about 47 years
H No 8-2-293/82/V/N/4 Vinayak Nagar
Film Nagar Hyderabad - 500 096                            Petitioner

                                 Vs

Kaja Suryanarayana S/o Late Kaja Somineedu
aged about 75 years
H No 8- 2- 293/82/F/C/14
Road No 9 Film Nagar Jubilee Hills Hyderabad - 500 096 & ors

                                                  .......... Respondents


The Court made the following:
                                      2



              HONOURABLE SRI JUSTICE P.NAVEEN RAO

 CIVIL REVISION PETITION Nos. 2433 OF 2022, 1 AND 9 OF 2023

COMMON ORDER:

Heard Sri Peri Prabhakar learned counsel for the petitioner in CRP No. 1 and 9 of 2023 and respondent no 1 in CRP 2433 of 2022 and Sri Mahit Reddy learned counsel for petitioner in CRP No. 2433 of 2022 and respondent no.4 in CRP Nos. 1 and 9 of 2023.

2. For the sake of convenience, parties are referred to as they were arrayed in Election O.P. 2.1. CRP 2433 of 2022 is filed by 4th respondent in Election O.P. No. 1 of 2021 and CRP Nos. 1 and 9 of 2023 are filed by petitioner in Election O P No. 1 of 2022 on the file of the Chief Judge-cum-Election Tribunal under Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation Act, City Civil Court, Hyderabad.

2.2. CRP 9 of 2023 is filed by petitioner challenging the orders dated 10.10.2022 in I A No. 3479 of 2022 in Election O P No. 1 of 2021 rejecting the application filed under Section 151 of CPC to conduct DNA test to determine the parenthood of child;

2.3. CRP No. 2433 is filed by 4th respondent challenging the orders dated 10.10.2022 in I A No. 3479 of 2022 in Election O P No. 1 of 2021 to the extent of directing production of records of two hospitals; 3

2.4. CRP 1 of 2023 is filed by petitioner challenging the orders dated 2.12.2021 passed in I A No. 3763 of 2022 in Election O P No. 1 of 2021 dismissing the application filed under Order XVI Rules 1 and 6 read with Section 151 of CPC to produce the documents at serial Nos. 1 to 16 mentioned in the petition.

3. The Election Notification for conducting 4th ordinary elections for the office of Ward Members of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (for short GHMC) was issued by the Telangana State Election Commission vide Election Notification No. 1294/TSEC-ULBs-GHMC/2020-1 dated 17.11.2020. Petitioner herein filed nomination and contested for the office of Ward Member of Ward No. 95- Jubilee Hills of GHMC on behalf of Telangana Rashtra Samithi (TRS) which is a recognized regional party in the State of Telangana. Respondents 4 to 9 were the other candidates who contested in the said election. 4th respondent contested on behalf of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) which is a recognised national party. Polling was held on 1.12.2020 and results were declared on 4.12.2020 wherein 4th respondent was declared successful by 3rd respondent as he has secured 10406 votes as against petitioner securing 9627 votes.

4. Section 21 of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation Act,1955 prescribes the disqualification for being elected as member. Section 21-A sets out the disqualification in general. As per Section 21-B 4 a person having more than two children shall be disqualified for election or from continuing as a member. All the contesting candidates have to submit declarations along with nomination form. Form-III declaration should be given to abide by the Code of Conduct and further declaration that he has not incurred any disqualification to the best of his knowledge and belief under Section 21-A and 21-B of the GHMC Act, 1955. Unless the said form is signed, the nomination papers are not accepted and the candidate is not permitted to contest. The 4th respondent filed Forms as required by these provisions disclosing that he has three children, second and third child being twins.

5. According to petitioner, even before the nomination of the 4th respondent was accepted, he has come to know that 4th respondent is having four children, as such he has submitted a representation on 21.11.2020 to the Returning Officer informing about 4th respondent having four children and requesting to verify the said fact and to disqualify 4th respondent. Petitioner also submitted the details of four children of 4th respondent along with their birth certificates.

6. The Returning Officer-3rd respondent has taken the written statement of 4th respondent. In the said written statement, 4th respondent denied that he has four children and given the particulars of his children.

5

7. According to 4th respondent, Derangula Sai Chandana is not his daughter and is his brother's daughter and submitted birth certificate and her details.

8. Third respondent rejected the objection raised by petitioner giving benefit of doubt to 4th respondent and accepted his nomination.

9. According to petitioner, the statement of 4th respondent about his children is blatant lie. According to petitioner the particular of birth certificates obtained by him and birth certificates submitted by 4th respondent are totally different. According to the Registrar of Birth and Deaths, the Birth Certificate No. 200607014874 digitally signed on 23.2.2016 submitted by the petitioner is genuine and certificate No. 200707021863 digitally signed on 29.10.2020 submitted by the 4th respondent is not available in records. According to petitioner, this clearly demonstrates that 4th child Derangula Sai Chandana was born on 10.7.2006 to 4th respondent and his wife D Vasantha and that her birth is registered at Serial No. 547 with date of Registration as 11.2.2006 and that she was born in Vijay Marie Hospital, Khairtabad. Further, the birth certificate submitted by 4th respondent to the Returning Officer is also declared as false and not found in the records by the very same Medical Officer. It is thus contended that 4th respondent has submitted false particulars to the Returning Officer and played fraud on the Election Authorities as well as Electorate. It is further submitted that in 6 so far as the other children are concerned, their birth certificates are also manipulated and the same are submitted with false dates. As per the original birth certificates, the first child Anil was born on 9.8.2001 in Vijay Krishna Nursing Home and second and third children Ramu and Laxman were born on 12.1.2003 in St Theresa's Hospital, whereas 4th respondent has submitted the birth certificate of the said children as though Anil was born in Nilofer Hospital on 9.8.2000 and Ramu and Laxman born on 15.8.2003 in Area Hospital, Vanasthalipuram.

10. Challenging the election of 4th respondent on the ground that he has four children, petitioner filed Election O.P. No. 1 of 2021 in the City Civil Court, Hyderabad.

11. In the said Election O.P., petitioner filed I A NO. 3763 of 2021 to summon the original records of the documents mentioned therein. He has filed I A No. 3479 of 2022 to direct 4th respondent, his wife and brother of 4th respondent to summon Derangula Sai Chandana for the purpose of conducting DNA test to determine parenthood of the child.

12. The Election Tribunal by order dated 2.12.2021 dismissed I.A.No.3763 of 2021. By order dated 10.12.2022 the Election Tribunal disposed of I A No. 3479 of 2022 directing summoning of records from Vijay Mary Hospital, Khairtabad and Nilofer Hospital, Hyderabad with respect to details of birth of Derangula Sai Chandana but rejected plea to 7 summon Derangula Sai Chandana to take blood samples to conduct DNA test to determine parenthood of the child.

13. According to learned counsel Sri Mahit Reddy for 4th respondent, Kumari Derangula Sai Chandana is not the daughter of 4th respondent but daughter of D.Ramesh and D.Lavanya, 4th respondent brother and sister-in-law. The petitioner is prosecuting a vexatious litigation and by filing application after application protracting the litigation. He would contend that after completion of recording of evidence by both parties and when matter was coming for oral arguments, petitioner filed I A No. 3479 of 2022.

14. He would submit that I A No. 3479 of 2022 was filed to subject Derangula Sai Chandana for DNA test. When the Election Tribunal refused to grant the said relief, it went beyond the prayer to direct production of birth records from two hospitals. It is further contended that this order is contrary to the order passed in I A Nos. 3762, 3763 and 3764 of 2022, and said order acts as res-judicata.

15. He would submit that it is settled principle of law that in an election dispute a child can not be subjected to DNA profile and it offends the child's right to privacy and right to be silent.

16. He would submit that documents marked as Ex.A6 to A.18 are already obtained under the Right to Information Act and the same 8 are admissible in evidence and there is no requirement to obtain certified copies. Learned counsel for the 4th respondent placed reliance on the following decisions.

i) Ashok Kumar Vs Raj Gupta and others1;

ii) Bachhaj Nahar vs. Nilima Mandal and another2;

iii) Aparna Ajinkya Firoda Vs Ajinkya Arun Firodia3.

17. Per contra, according to learned counsel Sri Peri Prabhakar for petitioner, the Election Tribunal grossly erred in not ordering DNA profile on Derangula Sai Chandana. According to learned counsel the documents secured by petitioner clearly point out that Derangula Sai Chandana is daughter of 4th respondent. If only the Tribunal ordered DNA profile of Derangula Sai Chandana entire controversy could have been resolved.

18. As the birth records produced by petitioner secured under Right to Information Act are not tallying with the bogus records filed by the 4th respondent, the Tribunal grossly erred in not summoning the records sought to be produced by the petitioner. Production of said record would help in going to the crux of the issue and in the interest of justice the record ought to have been called.

1 (2022) 1 SCC 20 2 (2008) 17 SCC 491 3 2023 SCC OnLine SC 161 9

19. Learned counsel Sri P.Prabhakar for the petitioner relied on following decisions:

i) Peruri Sooryaprakasam vs. P.I. Muniswami Chetti4;
ii) Shipping Corporation of India Ltd. Vs. Machado Brothers and others5;
iii) Immadabathuni Nagendramma and others vs. State of A.P., through the SHO Bapatla Town PS Guntur District, rep.by its PP High Court at Hyderabad and others6;
iv) Narayan Dutt Tiwari vs. Rohit Shekhar and another7; Mangal singh vs. Rallia and others8.

20. The issues that arise for consideration are:

1. Whether the Election Tribunal can order subjecting a child for DNA profile test who is unconcerned with the election petition and against her will and consent?
2. Whether the Election Tribunal erred in directing production of medical records from the hospitals?
3. Whether the Election Tribunal erred in dismissing application directing production of documents listed in I A No. 3763 of 2021?
4

AIR 1925 Mad 42 5 AIR 2004 SC 2093 6 2020 (2) ALT (Crl.) 251 (S.B.) 7 (2012) 12 SCC 554 8 AIR 1932 Lah 267 10 ISSUE No. 1:

21. In SANTOSH YADAV Vs NARENDER SINGH9 and BALDEV SINGH MANN Vs SURJIT SINGH DHIMAN10 Hon'ble Supreme Court held that standard of proof required in election dispute is very high and burden of proof is on the election petitioner to prove an allegation. Mere preponderance of probabilities are not enough, as may be the case in a civil dispute. Allegations should be clear and precise and charge should be proved to the hilt as in a criminal trial by clear, cogent and credible evidence. In SANTOSH YADAV, Supreme Court summarized the principles on improper acceptance of nominations. It is held that case has to be made out by raising specific pleadings setting out all material facts and adducing cogent evidence so as to enable a clear finding being arrived at. The burden of proving such material facts has to be discharged by the election petitioner by adducing positive, satisfactory and cogent evidence. If petitioner is unable to adduce such evidence the burden is not discharged and the election must stand. Difficulty of proof cannot obviate the need of strict proof or relax the rigour of required proof. The burden of proof placed on the election petitioner is very strict and so difficult to discharge as nearing almost impossibility. There is no room for any guesswork, speculation, surmises or conjectures i.e., acting on a mere possibility. The law requires proof. 9 (2002) 1 SCC 160 10 AIR 2009 SC 1045 11 How far that proof should go or what it should contain is not provided by the legislature.

22. In B.RAVI YADAV Vs CHERKULA UDAY KUMAR AND OTHERS11, Division Bench of this Court held as under:

"......To prove the charge of corrupt practice a mere preponderance of probabilities would not be enough. There would be a presumption of innocence available to the person charged. The charge shall have to be proved to the hilt, the standard of proof being the same as in a criminal trial. It is further held by the Apex Court that the success of a candidate who has won at an election should not be lightly interfered with. Any petition seeking such interference must strictly conform to the requirements of the law. Though the purity of the election process has to be safeguarded and the Court shall be vigilant to see that people do not get elected by flagrant breaches of law or by committing corrupt practices, the setting aside of an election involves serious consequences not only for the returned candidate and the constituency, but also for the public at large inasmuch as re-election involves an enormous load on the public funds and administration."

23. The above decisions are followed by this Court in LAGADAPATI RAJA GOPAL Vs SUNKARA KRISHNA MURTHY AND OTHERS12. This Court held "It is not the same thing as proof which comes later that the Court has to find whether the accused is guilty. It signifies that on first examination the matter appears to be self evident from the facts. In common law jurisprudence, prima facie case denotes evidence which (unless rebutted) would be sufficient to prove a particular proposition or fact".

11

2013 (1) ALD 733 (DB) 12 2010 (5) ALD 758 12 It is further held:

"The Court has to be watchful and ensure that conjectures or suspicions do not take the place of legal proof, but at the time of framing charge in a criminal case, what is required to be seen is whether the charge-sheet and the documents relied upon including the FIR and the statement of witnesses, if accepted as true at that stage would constitute a prima facie case. Prima facie evidence means, on the face of it, there is a ground for proceeding. It is not the same thing as proof which comes later that the Court has to find whether the accused is guilty. It signifies that on first examination the matter appears to be self evident from the facts. In common law jurisprudence, prima facie case denotes evidence which (unless rebutted) would be sufficient to prove a particular proposition or fact."

24. R.RAJAGOPAL Vs STATE OF T.N AND OTHERS13 is a case concerning right of privacy vis-à-vis freedom of press. Supreme Court summarized broad principles and held as under:

"26. We may now summarise the broad principles flowing from the above discussion:
(1) The right to privacy is implicit in the right to life and liberty guaranteed to the citizens of this country by Article 21. It is a "right to be let alone". A citizen has a right to safeguard the privacy of his own, his family, marriage, procreation, motherhood, child-bearing and education among other matters. None can publish anything concerning the above matters without his consent -- whether truthful or otherwise and whether laudatory or critical. If he does so, he would be violating the right to privacy of the person concerned and would be liable in an action for damages. Position may, however, be different, if a person voluntarily thrusts himself into controversy or voluntarily invites or raises a controversy."
13

1994 (6) SCC 632 13

25. In Selvi and others Vs State of Karnataka14, Supreme Court on review of the entire case law on issue of subjecting a person to Narcoanalysis, polygraph test (lie-detector test) and BEAP (Brain Electrical Activation Profile) test, held that test results cannot be admitted in evidence if they have been obtained through the use of compulsion. Article 20 (3) protects an individual's choice between speaking and remaining silent, irrespective of whether the subsequent testimony proves to be inculpatory or exculpatory. Article 20 (3) aims to prevent the forcible "conveyance of personal knowledge that is relevant to the facts in issue". The results obtained from each of the impugned tests bear a "testimonial" character and they cannot be categorised as material evidence. It is further held that "We have also elaborated how the compulsory administration of any of these techniques is an unjustified intrusion into the mental privacy of an individual. It would also amount to "cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment" with regard to the language of evolving international human rights norms." (para 263). It is further held that "no individual should be forcibly subjected to any of the techniques in question, whether in the contest of investigation in criminal cases or otherwise. Doing so would amount to an unwarranted intrusion into personal liberty. (para 264).

26. Right to privacy is implicit in right to life and liberty as enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution of India. No person's privacy 14 2010 (7) SCC 263 14 can be invaded much against the consent and will of that person. Certain exceptions to this rigid principle are carved out where larger public interest is involved and in matters concerning matrimonial cases. It is held that a person who is alleged to have been suffering with HIV disease can be subjected to medical examination even against his will as it is necessary to know his medical condition since it is likely to affect life of others also. Similarly, in personal law concerning relationship of husband and wife and the children born to such wedlock, the right to privacy is invaded to ascertain whether the marriage was consumed properly, whether the spouses to the marriage are suitable to live together or suffering from any disease which disentitles them to live as husband and wife. In matters where a marriage is sought to be nullified also it may be necessary to ascertain the health of one of the spouses of the marriage etc. To ascertain the birth of a child to the couple, DNA test can be ordered. Similarly, when it comes to the custody of a child, the mental condition of the spouse is also necessarily to be ascertained before Court orders the custody of the child to one of the parents. In all such circumstances, subjecting a person to medical examination does not amount to violating right of privacy. These are exceptions to normal rule.

27. As held by the Supreme Court in SANTOSH YADAV AND BALDEV SINGH MANN and this Court in LAGADAPATI RAJA GOPAL, in election matters the standard of proof is high and burden is on the 15 election petitioner. Mere preponderance of probabilities or presumptions cannot be the basis to challenge an election. The election proceedings are akin to criminal proceedings. In view of the above proposition of law on the subject, the burden lies on the petitioner to make specific allegations and lead evidence in support of said allegations. Petitioner in Election Petition cannot seek to elicit such information by subjecting a non-party to the election to medical examination.

28. In R.RAJAGOPAL, Supreme Court held that a citizen has a right to safeguard the privacy of procreation, motherhood, child bearing and education among others.

28.1. In Ashok Kumar (supra) Hon'ble Supreme Court observed that where other evidence is available to prove or dispute the relationship, the Court should ordinarily refrain from ordering blood tests. It is held that such tests impinge upon the right of privacy of an individual and could also have major societal repercussions. Hon'ble Supreme Court held:

"13. The presumption of legitimacy of a child can only be displaced by strong preponderance of evidence, and not merely by balance of probabilities. The material portion of the Court's opinion is produced hereinbelow : (Kamti Devi case [Kamti Devi v. Poshi Ram, (2001) 5 SCC 311 :
2001 SCC (Cri) 892] , SCC p. 316, para 11) "11. ... But at the same time the test of preponderance of probability is too light as that might expose many children to the peril of being illegitimatised. If a court declares that the husband is not the father of his wife's child, without tracing out its real father the fallout on the child is ruinous apart from all the ignominy visiting his mother.

The bastardised child, when grows up would be socially ostracised and can easily fall into wayward life. Hence, by way of abundant 16 caution and as a matter of public policy, law cannot afford to allow such consequence befalling an innocent child on the strength of a mere tilting of probability. Its corollary is that the burden of the plaintiff husband should be higher than the standard of preponderance of probabilities. The standard of proof in such cases must at least be of a degree in between the two as to ensure that there was no possibility of the child being conceived through the plaintiff husband."

14. It was also the view of the Court that the normal rule of evidence is that the burden is on the party that asserts the positive. But in instances where that is challenged, the burden is shifted to the party, that pleads the negative. Keeping in mind the issue of burden of proof, it would be safe to conclude that in a case like the present, the court's decision should be rendered only after balancing the interests of the parties i.e. the quest for truth, and the social and cultural implications involved therein. The possibility of stigmatising a person as a bastard, the ignominy that attaches to an adult who, in the mature years of his life is shown to be not the biological son of his parents may not only be a heavy cross to bear but would also intrude upon his right of privacy.

15. DNA is unique to an individual (barring twins) and can be used to identify a person's identity, trace familial linkages or even reveal sensitive health information. Whether a person can be compelled to provide a sample for DNA in such matters can also be answered considering the test of proportionality laid down in the unanimous decision of this Court in K.S. Puttaswamy (Aadhaar-5 J.) v. Union of India [K.S. Puttaswamy (Aadhaar-5 J.) v. Union of India, (2019) 1 SCC 1] , wherein the right to privacy has been declared a constitutionally protected right in India. The Court should therefore examine the proportionality of the legitimate aims being pursued i.e. whether the same are not arbitrary or discriminatory, whether they may have an adverse impact on the person and that they justify the encroachment upon the privacy and personal autonomy of the person, being subjected to the DNA test."

28.2. In Aparna Ajinkya Firoda (supra) the Hon'ble Supreme Court extensively considered the right to privacy and the rights of the children. In paragraph 60, Hon'ble Supreme Court culled out the principles governing DNA test. It reads:

"60. Having regard to the aforesaid discussion, the following principles could be culled out as to the circumstances under which a DNA test of a minor child may be directed to be conducted:
i. That a DNA test of a minor child is not to be ordered routinely, in matrimonial disputes. Proof by way of DNA profiling is to be directed in matrimonial disputes involving allegations of infidelity, only in matters where there is no other mode of proving such assertions.
17
ii. DNA tests of children born during the subsistence of a valid marriage may be directed, only when there is sufficient prima-facie material to dislodge the presumption under Section 112 of the Evidence Act. Further, if no plea has been raised as to non-access, in order to rebut the presumption under Section 112 of the Evidence Act, a DNA test may not be directed.
iii. A Court would not be justified in mechanically directing a DNA test of a child, in a case where the paternity of a child is not directly in issue, but is merely collateral to the proceeding.
iv. Merely because either of the parties have disputed a factum of paternity, it does not mean that the Court should direct DNA test or such other test to resolve the controversy. The parties should be directed to lead evidence to prove or disprove the factum of paternity and only if the Court finds it impossible to draw an inference based on such evidence, or the controversy in issue cannot be resolved without DNA test, it may direct DNA test and not otherwise. In other words, only in exceptional and deserving cases, where such a test becomes indispensable to resolve the controversy the Court can direct such test.
v. While directing DNA tests as a means to prove adultery, the Court is to be mindful of the consequences thereof on the children born out of adultery, including inheritance-related consequences, social stigma, etc."

28.3. The Hon'ble Supreme Court discussed on the child rights. Hon'ble Supreme Court held:

"66. In 1989, the United Nations Organisation drew up the Convention on Rights of Child with a view to provide special protection to children, proclaiming that "childhood is entitled to special care and assistance." The Declaration, inter-alia, recognises that a child, for full and harmonious development of his or her personality, should grow up in a family environment, in an atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding. The Declaration further emphasises the importance of family, as the "fundamental group of society and the natural environment for the growth and well-being of all its members and particularly children."

69. The concept of privacy for a child may not be equivalent to that of an adult. However, the evolving capacity of children has been recognised and the Convention acknowledges the control that individuals, including children, have over their own personal boundaries and the means by which they define who they are in relation to other people. Children are not to be deprived of this entitlement to influence and understand their sense of self simply by virtue of being children. Further, Article 8 of the Convention provides children with an express right to preserve their identity. Details of parentage are an attribute of a child's identity. Therefore, long-accepted notions about a child's parentage must not be frivolously challenged before Courts of Law.

18

Best interests of a child:

70. The phrase "mankind owes to the child the best it has to give" clearly underlines our duties towards children, and it entitles them to the best that mankind can give. This implies that the interest of the child should be given primary consideration in actions involving children." 28.4. In Narayan Dutt Tiwari (supra), Rohit Shekhar sought declaration that he is biological son of N.D.Tiwari and sought declaration. He filed I.A. under Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 to subject N.D.Tiwari to DNA test to determine parentage. In Immadabathuni Nagendramma (supra) the petitioners contended that Veeranjaneyulu falsely claimed himself as Kathi David Raju and secured caste certificate. During criminal investigation petition was filed to subject him to DNA test to establish their blood relationship. It is seen that in peculiar facts of those cases, DNA test was ordered.

29. In the instant case, child is not a party to the Election O.P. Therefore, the child can not be compelled to undergo DNA profile to ascertain her parents to decide the Election O.P. The child has a right to be silent. No one can be compelled to give up the right to privacy against the will of the child. The case on hand does not fall into the exceptions carved out from the normal principle on right to privacy, more particularly, when the child is not the person elected and is a stranger to the issue of earning disqualification by an elected candidate. A wrong declaration and a resultant disqualification relates to the 4th respondent. The child is no way concerned. She is a stranger to the election dispute. 19 Thus, she cannot be compelled to undergo medical examination against her will. Certainly subjecting the child to medical examination would offend her personal liberty, privacy and dignity of person that is bestowed on a girl child. There can be myriad reasons where the girl child would genuinely wish to keep the issue of her parenthood a secret. Moreover, she being a child, she can not give her consent for such tests and affecting her privacy, her parents can not subject her to DNA test.

30. Further by virtue of subjecting the child to medical examination at the instance of the petitioner in election petition, the factum of her parents would be in public domain and would be against the conscience and will of the person concerned and can have deleterious effect which cannot be repaired. The consequence of such medical examination can be far and wide.

31. I am therefore of the opinion that the Election Tribunal has rightly rejected the plea.

ISSUE No. 2:

32. In I A No. 3479 of 2022 the petitioner only prayed to subject Derangula Sai Chandana for DNA profile. The Election Tribunal was not persuaded to grant the said relief. That being so, the I A is liable to be dismissed. But strangely, the Election Tribunal observes that the petitioner ought to have asked for calling of records from Nilofer Hospital and Vijaya Mary Hospital instead of DNA test and then issues direction to the petitioner to summon records from Vijaya Mary Hospital, 20 Khairtabad and Nilofer Hospital, Hyderabad with respect to birth details of Derangula Sai Chandana. This direction of the Election Tribunal is in excess of jurisdiction. The Election Tribunal can not go beyond the prayer sought in the Interlocutory Application and grant a relief never sought by the petitioner. Further, as there was no relief sought, there was no occasion for the 4th respondent to contest the said aspect. Thus, the order to that extent is not sustainable. It is accordingly set aside. The Issue No.2 is answered accordingly.

ISSUE No.3:

33. At the time of recording petitioner's evidence Exhibits A 6 to A 18 were marked. Those exhibits were obtained under Right to Information Act. The Election Tribunal noticed that the Deputy Commissioner, GHMC filed an affidavit stating that all the relevant documents sought to be produced were already obtained and are already marked. Since said assertion is on oath, the Election Tribunal observed that no purpose would be served in calling for the documents. The Election Tribunal noticed the decision of this court in Datti Kameswari Vs singan Rao Sarath Chandra15 where it is held that Xerox copies certified by the designated Public Information Officer under the Right to Information Act are not certified copies within the meaning of Section 65 of the Evidence Act. Having regard to this view, the Election Tribunal observed that petitioner has not filed petition under Section 65 (a) (b) and 15 2015 SCC OnLine Hyd 389= (2016) 1 ALT 700 21 (c ) of Indian Evidence Act seeking to mark the documents obtained under Right to Information Act as secondary evidence. The Election Tribunal also observed that the petitioner had ample time to secure certified copies of the documents now sought to be summoned to prove genuineness of Exs.A.6 to A.18. For the aforesaid reasons, the application was dismissed.

34. Having regard to the facts of this case, I do not see any error in the opinion expressed by the Election Tribunal and its decision not to summon the records sought by the petitioner. The issue is answered accordingly.

35. In the result, C.R.P. Nos. 1 and 9 of 2023 are dismissed and C.R.P. No. 2433 of 2022 is allowed. No costs. Miscellaneous applications, if any pending, stand dismissed.
